paragraphs.text: Developers work in a wide variety of industries — most of them outside of what we traditionally call “tech.”
paragraphs.name: 144f

paragraphs.text: Even though software development is dominated by men, it’s becoming more diverse. Just one year ago, 93% of respondents were male. This time, only 89% were.
paragraphs.name: 31e7

paragraphs.text: 30% of all developers have been coding for less than 5 years.
paragraphs.name: 40c0
978a
paragraphs.text: Most of them work at companies with less than 500 employees.

paragraphs.name: 40c0
paragraphs.text: 30% of all developers have been coding for less than 5 years.

da630f543885.title: Very interesting information and appreciate your sharing for insight into 2016/2017 data and the…

paragraphs.text: Very interesting information and appreciate your sharing for insight into 2016/2017 data and the future.

61ece02827a6.title: It’s a shame they didn’t break down how people got their job by country.

paragraphs.text: It’s a shame they didn’t break down how people got their job by country.
In the UK I imagine it would be much higher % for external recruiters/headhunters. The vast majority of companies seem to outsource the whole recruitment process to these middle-men.
paragraphs.name: 4a03

paragraphs.text: With the 10 or so interviews I’ve had in the last 5 years, all but 1 were through external recruiters.

7997e1bc6fa6.title: This is the most curious of all the graphs.

paragraphs.text: This is the most curious of all the graphs. Why is there such a huge jump in the 20+ year developers, preceeded by very few developers in the 7 to 20 year period? The same time period in which the internet and computing have gone from a strong but outskirt industry to mainstream, to fundamental. There is an untold story or two here.
paragraphs.name: 16a6

6d919c1106d2.title: The count here is different from the other charts in that it’s not saying the total number of…

paragraphs.text: The count here is different from the other charts in that it’s not saying the total number of responses, but rather the total number of respondents who reported having a disability. I believe based on this that 1% of respondents were indeed blind.
paragraphs.name: 29b4

paragraphs.text: Once Stack Overflow releases their full dataset in a few months, we’ll be able to dig in and verify this.

bf9b7b5a6112.title: What surprises me the most from this survey is how loved Smalltalk is, and how a language from the…

paragraphs.text: What surprises me the most from this survey is how loved Smalltalk is, and how a language from the 80's is still used today. I’d love to know who uses it and in particular which industries it’s used in.

85622bf592bf.title: Super insightful, thanks for sharing and hashing this out!

paragraphs.text: Super insightful, thanks for sharing and hashing this out! We work with web devs who want to transition into making mobile apps with the skills/languages they already have, so it’s reassuring to see web and JS still so widespread and useful.
paragraphs.name: c19a

paragraphs.text: Awsome insight

bc3b21932532.title: Stack Overflow groups them by region, but as we know there can be huge income disparities between…

paragraphs.text: Stack Overflow groups them by region, but as we know there can be huge income disparities between different countries in the same region. We won’t really know how this breaks down until they release their full dataset.
paragraphs.name: 5c84

paragraphs.text: What I learned from Stack Overflow’s massive survey of 64,000 developers

virtuals.subtitle: Today Stack Overflow released the results of their 2017 survey of more than 64,000 developers.

content.subtitle: Today Stack Overflow released the results of their 2017 survey of more than 64,000 developers.

62aa88e60018.title: way back in the dot-com bubble, it was fairly common for new developers to be dubbed “associate” or…

paragraphs.text: way back in the dot-com bubble, it was fairly common for new developers to be dubbed “associate” or “integrator” with the implication that devising bespoke solutions was in their future, but that these young padawans have still got much to learn.
paragraphs.name: ca86

b1a9b318e4c0.title: I’m wondering how long will it take for Linus Torvalds to finally come to his senses and port Linux…

paragraphs.text: I’m wondering how long will it take for Linus Torvalds to finally come to his senses and port Linux kernel to JavaScript …

paragraphs.text: But seriously, who would have thought 10, 15 years ago that JavaScript would be so successful in and out side of web?

aa90f331f901.title: I have some insight to share with you.

paragraphs.text: I have some insight to share with you. The StackOverflow survey is far from reliable. Since it is largely a self-selecting survey, it is not statistically valid. Computerworld says that there are 18.2 million software developers around the world. The 64,000 survey participants represent about 0.35 per cent of the total. This sampling is completely…
paragraphs.name: af54

virtuals.subtitle: Here are some unanswered questions: How many developers chose not to participate in the survey because they were either too busy, or they…

content.subtitle: Here are some unanswered questions: How many developers chose not to participate in the survey because they were either too busy, or they…

d74304642fee.title: Hey ho. I’m NOT a coder, at all.

paragraphs.text: Hey ho. I’m NOT a coder, at all. Found the data informative, and did not see anywhere that the author purported that it represents the profession. Maybe I missed something.
paragraphs.name: 20e6

paragraphs.text: I’m most interested in the overall number of “developers” in the US, and how that breaks out over metri areas like SF, NYC, Boston, LA, etc. The remote work percentages were interesting, 11% full time remote.

94944862fef4.title: Is there any insight into spacial skewness of the survey?

paragraphs.text: Is there any insight into spacial skewness of the survey? It would seem to me that at least where wages are considered there seem to be little questionaires from poor countries. Where is the huge and growing tech sector from India? China? Are those represented at all? Would seem to me that if they were represented in terms of market share their…
paragraphs.name: ade4

953b191e343b.title: Curious where these “graphic designers” are making an average of $70K/year in the US.

paragraphs.text: Curious where these “graphic designers” are making an average of $70K/year in the US. Must’ve been a VERY small sampling, as I specifically left the design industry to move into front-end because I could make more at an entry-level position in web development than I could at the senior level in design. I’d be surprised if the national avera

1662772edff8.title: I think on the last one… out of the 1700ish people that identified themselves as having a…

paragraphs.text: I think on the last one… out of the 1700ish people that identified themselves as having a disability (out of the 50k or so that took the entire survey)… 1% of those people were blind and half a percent were deaf… so 17 people and about 9 people out of the 51,000 or so identified themselves as either deaf or blind. That makes more sense to me than 3 out of every 200. Am I reading that right?

6ece1b9a00e7.title: Is that a statistically significant difference?

paragraphs.text: Is that a statistically significant difference?

780b1f065cba.title: This survey is not scientific and means nothing other than “engineers” who participate in Stack…

paragraphs.text: This survey is not scientific and means nothing other than “engineers” who participate in Stack Overflow, (and anyone who has used it significantly realizes “engineer” is a stretch for most who use it), are mostly web developers. This is beyond useless information and crosses over into irresponsible. To suggest this survey should be the basis of…
